name: Black-and-white
title: Black and white
content: Black-and-white movies are known for their timeless appeal, often used to evoke nostalgia or to create a sense of timelessness. These movies, like The Kid or Modern Times, are often considered classics, with a focus on storytelling and character development. The OLS coefficient is quite high, meaning that critics are more likely to enjoy black-and-white movies than users.

name: New Hollywood
title: New Hollywood
content: The "New Hollywood" genre, emerging in the late 1960s, defied traditional filmmaking norms with a focus on realism, complex narratives, and anti-establishment themes. Movies like Easy Rider and Bonnie and Clyde marked a departure from studio conventions, influencing modern cinema and filmmakers like Martin Scorsese and Francis Ford Coppola. Naturally diverging from the norm, these movies are often not to the taste of the users, since their plots are convoluted and their staging occult. Targeting the critics, it's no surprise to see this genre strongly influences the rating difference, with a positive 8.3 OLS score.

name: Drama
title: Drama
content: Drama movies are known for their focus on character development and complex narratives, often featuring realistic characters and settings. These movies, like Titanic or The Shawshank Redemption, are often considered classics, with a focus on storytelling and character development. The OLS coefficient is quite high, meaning that critics are more likely to enjoy drama movies than users. The confidence interval is quite small since its the most represented genre in the dataset.

name: Action
title: Action
content: Action movies are known for their fast-paced plots, often featuring high-stakes conflict and intense action sequences. These movies, like The Dark Knight or The Matrix, are often considered classics, with a focus on storytelling and character development. The OLS coefficient is quite high, meaning that critics are more likely to enjoy action movies than users. The confidence interval is quite small since its one of the most represented genre in the dataset.

name: Gross-out
title: Gross-out
content: The gross-out movie genre is known for its crude and explicit humor, aiming to provoke strong reactions through shock or disgust. These movies, like American Pie or There's Something About Mary, are often considered classics, with a focus on storytelling and character development. The OLS coefficient is quite high, meaning that critics are more likely to enjoy gross-out movies than users. The confidence interval is quite small since its one of the most represented genre in the dataset.

name: Slapstick
title: Slapstick
content: Slapstick movies are known for exaggerated physical comedy, visual gags, and absurd humor, often featuring pratfalls and slapstick violence. Classics like Charlie Chaplin's works or Home Alone exemplify the genre's enduring appeal in providing lighthearted entertainment through playful and exaggerated humor. These two examples may also illustrate why this genre is slightly preferred by users. While that kind of humor might always work on users, critics often get bored when using the same pattern over and over, leading to good scores to first movies of the genre, and lower scores for more recent ones.

name: Bollywood
title: Bollywood
content: Bollywood genre movies offer a diverse mix of colorful musicals, intense action, and heartfelt dramas. It's possible to assimilate this genre to American superproduction, but may fail to encompass the richness of the genre. Logically more turned to mass consumption, the logical result is a negative coefficient, toward users, but the high variance could be explained by the culture of the IMDb user base, since most of them might simply not grasp the qualities of Bollywood movies, since they're not aimed to occidental public. This reminds us that this study is logically centered on western culture, from the origin of the data to the ratings themselves.

name: Inspirational Drama
title: Inspirational Drama
content: With a big OLS coefficient of -8, this subgenre focuses on narratives that uplift and motivate audiences through stories of triumph over adversity. These movies often draw from real-life events, biographies, or fictional tales with strong moral or motivational themes, anchored in dark stories. For instance, Will Smith often starred in that kind of publicly acclaimed movies, such as The Pursuit of Happyness or Seven Pounds. The confidence interval is quite large since only a few movies represent that genre.
